newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Hot Brazil Telecom CRT eyes local bolsa listing.
newsitem.headline: Hot Brazil Telecom CRT eyes local bolsa listing.

text.p: Already an over-the-counter star in Brazil, state-owned Companhia Riograndense de Telecomunicacoes S.A. (CRT) now hopes to list on the Sao Paulo bolsa.
"Certainly it's a goal but it won't happen in the short term. It'll be more like the medium or long term," Ocelio Ledur, CRT's market relations director, told Reuters.

A listing on South America's largest bourse would lend "transparency" to trade in CRT shares and improve the stock's liquidity although the company has no immediate plans to raise money with a stock issue, he said.

Most analysts are sure a Rio Grande do Sul state-owned CRT listing in Sao Paulo will be successful. The company already is one of the most sought-after issues among Brazil's coveted telecoms, behind only federal giant Telebras
The company is already the darling of investors in Rio de Janeiro's fledgling SOMA over-the-counter market, where it regularly accounts for 65 percent of daily trade or volume totaling $8 million.
Interest was sparked in CRT after a group led by Brazil's RBS and Spain's Telefonica de Espana bought a 35 percent stake last December.
"Everybody remembers what they (Telefonica) did with Telefonica del Peru two years ago," said analyst Maxim Medvedovsky of local bank Banco Icatu.
"After they bought it, it was a great investment for portfolio managers," he said.
CRT's preferred A share already has risen nearly 70 percent since it began trading on the SOMA on Nov 11, when it started at 80.00 reais. It closed Tuesday at 133.95 reais.

While the firm remains majority state-owned, it will be operated by Telefonica and experts anticipate it will post impressive results in the coming years as it grows quickly to meet huge pent-up demand.
In a sign of its growing attractiveness to investors outside Brazil, U.S.-based Salomon Brothers announced Wednesday it had added CRT to its Brazilian holdings.
CRT posted a net profit of 19.95 million reais in 1997's first quarter, up from 9.783 million reais in the same period last year, Ledur said.

It ended 1996 with a 16 million-real loss mostly from non-recurring losses of 103 million reais, including a 73 million real expense related to its voluntary retirement personnel reduction plan, he added.
Ledur said the company expects to have installed 250,000 fixed lines and 200,000 cellular terminals this year.
